subject: Re: Digest Number 1845
msgSnippet: ... Bob, While I don t agree with you 100% on Test First being THE solution, or THE right approach in ALL cases, I am definitely more in your camp than not.
rawEmail:

Subject: Re: Digest Number 1845

> I wear a green wrist band that says "Test First".  It is a symbol of  
> =
my commitment to this minmium level of professional ethics.  I WILL  
> TES=
T MY CODE.

Bob,

While I don't agree with you 100% on Test First being THE=
 solution, or
THE right approach in ALL cases, I am definitely more in your=
 camp
than not.

When Roongko and I were at SunLabs, we headed a research p=
roject
called ADL (Assertion Definition Language) that was close in spirit =
to
test first: designers/developers would write the spec for the code
befor=
e writing it.  The spec included both syntax (e.g. the method
signature) as=
 well as semantics (what the method was supposed to do in
terms of assertio=
ns (the A in ADL) - for example: if X < 0 throw
InvalidArgumentException)).=


The spec would serve as a guide for the developers: "I have to write
code=
 that throws an InvalidArgumentException when X is less than 0".

The spec =
was also used to automatically generate tests that would
validate the speci=
fied behavior (e.g. pass -1 and check to see if the
InvalidArgumentExceptio=
n is thrown).

Not exactly test first, but the same basic idea: the code wa=
s not
"done" until the tests (generated directly from the spec therefore
in=
-sync with the spec) passed.

The system worked just fine, but there was a =
big problem.  Most
developers did not want to write specs first.  Let me be=
 more
specific: some of them did not want to, others could not do it. Some
=
developers, including some very good ones, are not wired to think test
firs=
t.  They could do it, but they would not be very effective at it -
like ask=
ing a left-handed person to write with their write hand.

Now, we could fir=
e all people who refuse to, or are not good at test
first, but I don't thin=
k that will work.  Over the years, and by
looking at the way the world work=
s (which I know is far from ideal), I
have come to the conclusion that tryi=
ng to globally change some
behaviors (even when the new behavior is so obvi=
ously best for
everyone (think smoking, eating junk, ..., not writing tests=
 before
writing your code)) is a noble, but pointless pursuit.  Some people=

are going to be easily changed (the test infected ones in our
discussions =
- say ~30%), others might change with some effort and over
time - say anoth=
er ~30%, but many are not going to be changed.

Let me attempt a simple ana=
logy...

We all know that a bad diet leads to cholesterol and heart-disease=
. 
Ideally all people should clean-up their diet and start exercising
regul=
arly, but we know that's not going to happen, or happen fast
enough to save=
 some lives.  Cholesterol reducing drugs could be seen
as an excuse to not =
control diet and exercise (the way you say that
some tools could be used by=
 developers as an excuse to not write
tests) but I am sure you would not wi=
thold them from people who are
not willing to be virtuous and change their =
ways.  The goal is to
lower cholesterol and for most people the best approa=
ch is to clean-up
their diet AND take the drugs.  Over-time they may get of=
f the drugs,
but diet and exercise alone are simply not sufficient for a lo=
t of people.

Similarly, when it comes to developing code I agree with you =
100% that
developers should take responsibility for unit testing their own =
code
(although I don't feel as strong as you do about test *first*, testing=

and testing well is what's most important to me).

And I believe that the =
most effective way to get developers to test
their code is to give them too=
ls (JUnit is one, Agitator is another)
to make them as efficient and as eff=
ective as possible.  To me, the
desirable end result is well designed, well=
 tested, well understood
code using whatever methodology, technology, and t=
ools are available
and work best for the code and the people in question.

=
>My problem is that I just don't know if the  
>Agitation features of Agita=
r are really particularly useful.   

I don't know how to respond to that e=
xcept to, perhaps, schedule a
couple of days working *together* on real cod=
e to show you all the
benefits that you get from agitation.  For example, d=
o you know that
you can use Agitator in a test-first way?  Again, we did no=
t wake  up
one morning looking for a problem to solve with our technology. =
 I
believe that the core ideas behind agitation are not only useful, but
in=
dispensable.

> Moreover I fear a tool that can figure out tests for you ma=
y give  
> developers an excuse not to write their own tests; 

Ah, you are=
 missing one VERY CRITICAL point here.  Unlike other test
automation produc=
ts, Agitator does not "figure out" tests for you.
That's a key concept behi=
nd the agitation - without developer
intervention all you could test is tha=
t the code does what the code
does - we don't do that. Instead, we help you=
 analyze the code by
showing you how it behaves, but without developer inte=
raction, and
without a developer looking at observations and promoting them=
 to
assertions, or adding their own assertions there are NO TESTS and no
te=
st points.  Please refer to my spreadsheet analogy in another post -
think =
of Agitator as a tool to accelerate, amplify, and add depth to
your testing=
 effort (even your test-first efforts).

>especially if it  
> is marketed =
to managers and developers as a way to reduce unit test  
> writing time.

=
I don't believe that unit test *writing* *time* is the right thing to
look =
at.  Using that time effectively is most important.  Sometimes
using JUnit =
is the most effective way to test (e.g. when you have a
very specific seque=
nce of operations in mind (as you mention in your
examples).  Other times, =
using Agitator is the most effective way to
test (e.g. when you want to spe=
cify and test a class or method
invariant with a lot of valid and invalid i=
nputs). 

I believe that the most effective use of testing time *must* incl=
ude a
tool like Agitator to help developers think about, discover, analyze,=

all the possible behaviors of their code and generate powerful and
broad (=
data-driven) regression tests to complement more specific JUnit
tests when =
they exists.

OK, my word-count for the day is up.  I hope that someone oth=
er than
the two of us reads these posts (feel free to chime in) otherwise w=
e
might as well continue this conversation over a couple of beers :-).

Alb=
erto (Test-first, test-during, test soon after, but please test!)









=

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
> 
> O=
n May 31, 2006, at 3:15 AM, junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> 
> >    Date: Tu=
e May 30, 2006 11:44 am (PDT)
> >    From: "albsavoia" albsavoia@...
> > Su=
bject: JUnit *AND* Agitator
> >
> > Hi Bob,
> >
> > I appreciate your parti=
cipation and opinions on this topic.
> 
> Hello Alberto, great to talk with=
 you.
> > Questions, discussions, and constructive criticism will help all =
of us
> >  learn more about the problems and challenges of testing and how =
to
> > address them.
> >
> > So let me start :-).  I will start not by talk=
ing about Agitator, but
> > about a more general issue: is there a problem =
with unit testing that
> > needs solving?
> >
> > You write:
> >
> >> The b=
ottom line is that this is a very interesting product that
> >> appears to =
me to be looking for a problem to solve.
> >
> > I believe that there's a H=
UGE and GROWING problem to solve.  My
> > co-founder (Dr. Roongko Doong, an=
other person who is as passionate
> > about advancing the state-of-the-art =
in test automation for 15+
> > years), started Agitar not because we were l=
ooking for something to
> > do, or make a quick buck (quite the contrary, i=
n 2002 when we started
> > Agitar I was Senior Director of Software Enginee=
ring at Google - if
> > all I cared about was money I would have stayed put=
 :-)).
> 
> Let me be clear.  There was an old joke in the '60s about the L=
aser  
> being a solution in search of a problem.  I was making an oblique =
 
> reference to that old joke, and not a snide remark about  
> commercial=
ism.  I think the agitation technology is very cool.  I'm  
> just wonderin=
g what problem it solves.
> 
> I agree with you that there is a huge and gr=
owing problem in software  
> quality, and that test automation is the solu=
tion to that problem.   
> I'm just perplexed about how Agitar addresses th=
at issue.
> 
> > We started
> > Agitar to solve what I believe is one of th=
e biggest problems in
> > software development, and one that we are very pa=
ssionate about:
> > getting developers to think about and do testing DURING=
 development -
> > so they can address defects and design problems with max=
imum
> > efficiency and minimum impact.  As opposed to the more traditional=

> > "throw the code over the wall to QA" model.
> 
> I completely agree th=
at the over-the-wall method is broken.  I think  
> it's broken for many re=
asons.
> 
> 1. Tests are done at the end of the schedule when there's no ti=
me  
> left (because all the slack has been eaten up by the developers.)
> =

> 2. Manual tests are very costly, time consuming, and error prone;  
> es=
pecially when they come at the end and are under schedule pressure.
> 
> 3.=
 Tests that come at the end are based on the *current* execution of  
> the=
 program rather than on the true requirements.  This is a bizarre  
> break=
 in encapsulation which tends to let the implementation drive  
> the requi=
rements.
> 
> > My experience at Google, where with others I championed the=

> > introduction of JUnit and the idea of developer testing was very
> > r=
evealing.  Admittedly, Google is a way off the chart in terms of
> > progra=
mming talent,
> 
> And way off the charts in assisting repressive nations.
=
> 
> > but in the last 4 years I confirmed the very same
> > findings with =
100s of other people and software organizations that
> > also introduced, o=
r tried to introduce, developer/unit testing:
> >
> > Here are some of the =
key things I discovered:
> >
> > 1) On average, approximately only 30% of d=
evelopers who are introduced
> > to xUnit/developer-testing/TDD become test=
-infected (i.e. the will
> > continue to do unit testing even if they are n=
ot asked to).  The other
> > 70% will go back to their "old-ways".  Why is =
that?  My next points
> > sheds some light.
> >
> > 2) Most developer compl=
ained that in order to get decent coverage (say
> > 80-90%) they have to wr=
ite 3-4 lines of JUnit code for every line of
> > Java.  They wanted some w=
ay to automate the most mundane parts of the
> > testing effort and retain =
control of the areas that require human
> > intelligence, insight, domain-k=
nowledge, and creativity.
> >
> > 3) Most of the unit tests that actually g=
et written cover only the
> > normal/"happy" path.  They assume the best of=
 all possible world; that
> > they would never be passed bad parameters, th=
at all strings would be
> > nice ASCII code and never exceed some magic len=
gth, that all objects
> > will be well formed and in the state they were ex=
pecting, etc.
> > Needless to say, this is not sufficient for most industri=
al
> > applications, especially if they have to survive in hostile
> > envi=
ronments where hackers look for every possible deficiency in the
> > system=
, or when your colleagues assume that you are going to handle
> > those nul=
l pointers so he does not have to worry about them. On the
> > other hand, =
if you want to cover all those contingencies testing
> > becomes a combinat=
orial problem and it's hard for developers to
> > conceive of and test for =
everything that should be tested for.
> >
> > 4) If testing a particular pi=
ece of code was too complicated (lots of
> > dependencies, complicated set-=
up, lots of things to mock, etc.) the
> > tests were skipped.  This is huma=
n nature. Ideally people would look
> > at code that's difficult to test an=
d think re-factoring and (re)design
> > for testability but most people are=
 not there yet.
> >
> > 5) Test maintenance was as time consuming as code m=
aintenance.  If
> > there's anything that most developers disliked more tha=
n writing lots
> > of test code by hand, was maintaining that code.  One of=
 the most
> > common unit test maintenance patterns is: delete or comment-o=
ut
> > failing tests.
> 
> My solution to all these "problems" is to re-edu=
cate the developers  
> and fire the ones who don't realize that they can't=
 release untested  
> code.  This seems to me to be a matter of professiona=
l ethics.  I  
> have no sympathy for whining software developers who don't=
 want to  
> write tests.  What they are really whining about is that they =
don't  
> want to be responsible for making their code work.
> 
> Writing t=
ests first (i.e. true TDD) solves most of the problems  
> mentioned above =
except the discipline problem.  Pink slips solve that  
> problem.  (I'm de=
ad serious about this.  You don't test, you don't  
> work. Period.)
> 
> U=
sing TDD you can't write production code unless you write a failing  
> uni=
t test first.  Thus you will get very high coverage (80-90), and  
> you wo=
n't write code that's hard to test, because you write the tests  
> first.
=
> 
> Refactoring solves the test maintenance problem.  Tests are not  
> se=
cond class citizens.  They have to be kept to the same standard of  
> clea=
nliness and design as production code.  Therefore we refactor  
> them to k=
eep them easy to modify.
> >
> > So, for someone who believes that develope=
r/unit testing is the right
> > thing to do - one of the MOST important thi=
ngs to do and do WELL - I
> > saw a VERY big and VERY definite problem.  Na=
mely: Most developers
> > want and need help with their testing effort.  Wi=
thout some help and
> > automation they will either give up on developer/un=
it testing or, even
> > worse because it gives a false sense of security, w=
rite some trivial
> > "happy-path" tests that pass too easily and fail to c=
over some
> > critical conditions.
> 
> Again, developers who have the atti=
tude that it is OK to give up on  
> testing need their attitude readjusted=
 -- and fast!  I have no  
> problem with tools to help with this; but the =
first problem to solve  
> is the attitude problem.
> 
> Also, one of my pr=
oblems with the Agitar tool is that it can't seem  
> to see very far into =
a function.  Therefore the observations it makes  
> are naive, thus possib=
ly reinforcing the "false sense of security"  
> you talked about.
> 
> > N=
ote that I am not in favor of complete
> > automation (press a button get s=
ome passing tests) unless you need
> > some quick change detector. I want A=
gitator to do for software
> > developers what spreadsheets have done for a=
ccountants and business
> > people: raise the level of abstraction, allow t=
he user to focus on the
> > important things that require their intelligenc=
e and understanding
> > (e.g. formulae in spreadsheets, test data/assertion=
s in Agitator),
> > provide a number of other related utilities (e.g. graph=
s in
> > spreadsheets, code coverage and code rules and dashboard reports i=
n
> > Agitator).
> 
> I like the code coverage aspects of Agitar.  Some of =
the graphs and  
> charts are very useful.  I have no problems with them at=
 all.
> >
> > We could argue whether Agitator helps with some of the proble=
ms (I
> > believe it does since it was designed to address them specificall=
y),
> > but I don't think we can argue that there is no problem to be solve=
d
> > when it comes to developer testing.  Until most developers and
> > so=
ftware development organizations practice thorough unit testing on a
> > co=
nsistent basis, we have a problem.
> 
> Agreed.  And tool support is import=
ant.  Education is even more  
> important.  There is a minimum level of pr=
ofessional ethics involved  
> here, and every developer needs to learn it.=

> 
> I wear a green wrist band that says "Test First".  It is a symbol of =
 
> my commitment to this minmium level of professional ethics.  I WILL  
>=
 TEST MY CODE.
> >
> > Without JUnit we would not be where we are today.  A=
 30% test
> > infection rate is a huge step from what it was before (i.e. ~=
0%).  But
> > I refuse believe that we cannot augment and provide developer=
s with
> > other tools beyond JUnit, and that we are stuck at 30% test infe=
cted.
> 
> I agree.  And I think JUnit was partially responsible for this. =
  
> However I also think that the revolution would have happened without  =

> the tool -- causing the tool to be written anyway.
> >
> > There's work =
we all have left to do.
> >
> > People like you are helping our common caus=
e doing what you do best
> > and, presumably, like to do best: training, co=
aching, mentoring,
> > educating, writing, etc.
> >
> > Me?  I am a softwar=
e tool maker.  That's what I do best, and that's
> > what I like to do. Tha=
t's the best way I can help the cause.  I
> > believe that tools are critic=
al to progress, and that the right tools
> > will enable the right behavior=
.  Anyone who knows me, or has talked
> > with me for just a few minutes, k=
nows how passionate I am about
> > solving this problem (if we agree that t=
here is a problem :-)) and I
> > also would like to think that in addition =
to my passion, I bring some
> > unique experience, skills, and vision to th=
e table.
> 
> And I appreciate that!  I think we need more and better tools=
 for  
> software development.  My problem is that I just don't know if the=
  
> Agitation features of Agitar are really particularly useful.   
> More=
over I fear a tool that can figure out tests for you may give  
> developer=
s an excuse not to write their own tests; especially if it  
> is marketed =
to managers and developers as a way to reduce unit test  
> writing time.
>=
 
>
